{{Infobox terrorist attack |title=Dawson College shooting |image=DawsonShooting1.jpg |image_size=250px |caption=The [[Dawson College]] campus on de Maisonneuve Boulevard minutes after the shooting |location=[[Montreal]], [[Quebec]], Canada |target=[[Dawson College]] |date={{start date and age|2006|09|13}} |time={{nowrap|12:42 p.m.–1:02 p.m.}} |timezone=[[Eastern Time Zone|EDT]] |victim=Anastasia De Sousa |type=[[School shooting]], [[spree killer|spree shooting]], [[murder-suicide]] |fatalities=2 (including the perpetrator) |injuries=19 |perp=[[Kimveer Gill|Kimveer Singh Gill]] |weapons= * [[Beretta Cx4 Storm]] [[Semi-automatic rifle|semi-automatic carbine]] * [[Glock 21]] [[.45 ACP|.45-caliber]] [[semi-automatic pistol]] * [[Norinco HP9-1]] short [[pump-action shotgun]] |motive=Various, possible [[bullying]], personal stress, [[Depression (mood)|depression]] }} The '''Dawson College shooting''' occurred on September 13, 2006 at [[Dawson College]], a [[CEGEP]] located in [[Downtown Montreal|downtown]] [[Montreal]], [[Quebec]], Canada. The perpetrator, [[Kimveer Gill]], began shooting outside the [[de Maisonneuve Boulevard]] entrance to the school, and moved towards the atrium by the cafeteria on the main floor.{{cite news | title = The Montreal Killer Was a Death-Obsessed Goth | work = Toronto Daily News | date = 2006-09-14 | url = http://www.torontodailynews.com/index.php/WorldNews/2006091420montreal-gunman | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080316090826/http://www.torontodailynews.com/index.php/WorldNews/2006091420montreal-gunman | archivedate = 2008-03-16 | accessdate = 2006-09-15}}{{cite news |title=Gunman opens fire at Dawson College |work=[[The Gazette (Montreal)|The Gazette]] |date=2006-09-13 |url=http://www.canada.com/montrealgazette/news/story.html?id=6332c17e-c92a-4427-a98d-4678301674e3 |accessdate=2006-09-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061021021906/http://www.canada.com/montrealgazette/news/story.html?id=6332c17e-c92a-4427-a98d-4678301674e3 |archivedate=2006-10-21 |df= }} One victim died at the scene, while another 19 were injured, eight of whom were listed in critical condition, with six requiring surgery.{{cite news|title=Press Release|work=Service de police de la ville de Montréal|date=September 13, 2006|url=http://www.spvm.qc.ca/fr/documentation/3_1_2_communiques.asp?nocomm=389}}{{cite news|title=UPDATE 7-Gunman kills one, wounds 19 at Montreal college|work=[[Reuters]]|date=September 13, 2006|url=http://today.reuters.com/news/articlebusiness.aspx?type=tnBusinessNews&storyID=nN13394701|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080204004211/http://today.reuters.com/news/articlebusiness.aspx?type=tnBusinessNews&storyID=nN13394701|archivedate=2008-02-04|accessdate=2006-09-14}}{{cite news|title=Woman, gunman dead in Montreal school rampage|work=[[CBC News]]|date=2006-09-13|url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/2006/09/13/shots-dawson.html|accessdate=2006-09-13}} The shooter later committed [[suicide]] by shooting himself in the head, after being shot in the arm by a police officer.{{cite news|title=Montreal gunman killed himself: autopsy|work=[[CBC News|CBC]]|date =2006-09-14 |url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/2006/09/14/qc-dawsoninvestigation.html|accessdate=2006-09-15}} It was the third fatal [[school massacre|school shooting]] in Montreal, after the [[École Polytechnique massacre]] in 1989 and the [[Concordia University massacre|shooting spree]] at [[Concordia University]] in 1992. == Timeline of events == === Shooting === [[File:Dawson-shooting-map.svg|thumb|330px|'''1.''' 12:30: Shooter exits his car.
'''2.''' 12:41: First shots fired outside entrance.
'''3.''' 12:44: Nearby officers rush to the scene.
'''4.''' 12:42–12:48: Gunman fires on students in the cafeteria. Police shoot him in the arm, he kills himself with a shot to the head.
'''5.''' 1:30: Killer's body is dragged outside and covered.]] At 12:30 p.m. [[Eastern Daylight Time|EDT]], Gill parked his car on de Maisonneuve Boulevard near the college campus and was seen removing weapons from his trunk by bystanders. Gill briefly took a passerby hostage and forced him to carry a bag containing a fourth gun and additional ammunition. Gill opened fire at students outside on the steps of Dawson College at its rear entrance with a [[semi-automatic rifle|semi-automatic]] carbine, and the passerby fled the melee, leaving Gill's bag.{{cite web |url=http://tvanouvelles.ca/lcn/infos/regional/archives/2006/09/20060915-200401.html |title=Le geste de Kimveer Gill était prémédité |accessdate=2007-08-06| author= |date=2006-09-15|publisher=LCN|language=French}} Gill then entered the school and made his way to the cafeteria, almost directly ahead of the school entrance. He positioned himself in the corner of the building, near the microwave oven, and set his bag on the floor. He loaded a pistol, fired a shot into the floor and then shot students who were standing in front of him. He then raised his weapon and ordered the remaining students to lie down on the floor. He continued shooting at students until confronted by two police officers who had been visiting the school at the time regarding an unrelated incident. The police officers entered after hearing the gunfire, and rushed to the cafeteria. Additional police officers surrounded the campus. Confronted by police officers in the school cafeteria, Gill briefly took two more people hostage.{{cite web |url=http://tvanouvelles.ca/lcn/infos/regional/archives/2006/09/20060914-221128.html |title=Le drame minute par minute |accessdate=2007-08-05| author= |date=2006-09-14|publisher=LCN|language=French}} He was shot in the arm by police officer Denis Côté and then committed suicide via a gunshot wound to the head at 12:48 EDT. The police officers attempted to resuscitate him, but failed. At 1:30 p.m., police officers dragged his body outside the building, covered it with a yellow bag, then continued the evacuation and the search for possible accomplices.{{cite news|last=Couvrette|first=Phil|title=Montreal Shooting Rampage Kills Student|agency=Associated Press|publisher=[[Forbes]]|date=2006-09-13|url=https://www.forbes.com/business/feeds/ap/2006/09/13/ap3015809.html|accessdate=2006-09-14}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}{{cite news|title=Gunman in Montreal College shooting called himself 'angel of death'|work=[[CBC News|CBC]]|date=14 September 2006|url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/2006/09/14/gunman-shooting.html|accessdate=2006-09-14}} Authorities concluded the attack was premeditated, after a short [[suicide note]] was found on Gill's body during the autopsy.{{cite web |url=http://tvanouvelles.ca/lcn/infos/regional/archives/2006/09/20060915-165141.html |title=Anastasia De Sousa a reçu neuf balles |accessdate=2007-08-05| author= |date=2006-09-15|publisher=LCN|language=French}} === Immediate aftermath === {{more citations needed|section|date=September 2017}} Police cordoned off the campus area with orange police tape and swept the school for students left inside. {{cite web |url=http://www.canada.com/topics/news/story.html?id=1dc31f5a-940d-4147-b5c7-d693b38f4f35&k=66350 |title=Dawson College victim succumbs to injuries |date=2006-09-14 |accessdate=2007-08-06 |publisher=Montreal Gazette |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070507115234/http://www.canada.com/topics/news/story.html?id=1dc31f5a-940d-4147-b5c7-d693b38f4f35&k=66350 |archivedate=2007-05-07 }} Local radio reports placed the number of police vehicles at approximately 80 and up to 24 ambulances surrounded the building. Students and faculty were evacuated from the campus or left the vicinity of the shooting. Two shopping centres adjacent to Dawson, [[Place Alexis Nihon]] and [[Westmount Square]], directly linked to the [[Atwater (Montreal Metro)|Atwater metro station]], were evacuated and [[Line 1 Green (Montreal Metro)|the green line]] of the Montreal Metro was shut down for several hours between [[Lionel-Groulx (Montreal Metro)|Lionel-Groulx]] and [[McGill (Montreal Metro)|McGill]].{{cite news|title=La fusillade a fait deux morts et 19 blessés |work=[[Canadian Press]] |publisher=cyberpresse.ca ([[La Presse (Canada)|La Presse]]) |language=French |date=2006-09-13 |url=http://www.cyberpresse.ca/article/20060913/CPFRONTPAGE/60913099/5032/CPACTUALITES |accessdate=2006-09-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061006140323/http://www.cyberpresse.ca/article/20060913/CPFRONTPAGE/60913099/5032/CPACTUALITES |archivedate=October 6, 2006 }} The [[Pepsi Forum]] entertainment centre, opposite the eastern corner of Dawson, was open when many of the students came running into the premises to seek refuge moments after the shooting began. Shortly afterward, the Pepsi Forum went into lockdown under the directives of the Montreal Police. Eventually, one of the Forum's entrances onto St. Catherine Street re-opened under police/security guard to allow monitored access and egress. [[File:Dawson College shooting - 2006 - Montreal (243069228).jpg|thumb|right|300px|Sign on the door of a downtown [[Montreal Metro|Montreal metro]] station in the afternoon of the shooting, inviting Dawson students to [[Concordia University]] for shelter while subway service is halted.]] A large number of the evacuees were also directed to the nearby [[Concordia University (Quebec)|Concordia University]], where the Concordia Student Union (CSU) is located. The CSU cancelled all remaining Orientation activities, and instead used its venues to temporarily shelter the evacuated Dawson students and provide them with food, water, blankets, and phones to reach other loved ones. A coordination team was put in place from the CSU and the DSU used the Sir George Williams campus as a temporary crisis centre and offered counselling (psychologist, psychiatrist) to traumatized students and staff. [[Claude Dauphin (politician)|Claude Dauphin]] (Mayor of the borough of Lachine and Vice-President of the City of Montreal executive committee) had a very close relationship with both of the student unions during the night of the events; Dauphin went to the CSU office's the night of the shooting to meet with both unions to inform them of what the city was doing, and to ask how he could help. The police also established several phone numbers for parents and friends of the students.{{cite press release|title=Shooting at Dawson College: preliminary statement (press release 2)|publisher=[[Service de police de la Ville de Montréal|Montreal Police Service]]|date=2006-09-13|url=http://www.spvm.qc.ca/EN/documentation/3_1_2_communiques.asp?noComm=387|accessdate=2006-09-13}} Police reported that they needed a few days to process the crime scene. As a result, officials from Dawson College stated that the school would be closed until Monday, September 18, 2006,{{cite news|last=Dimanno|first=Rosie|title=Mayhem and murder on Montreal campus, again|work=[[Toronto Star]]|date=2006-09-14|url=https://www.thestar.com/NASApp/cs/ContentServer?pagename=thestar/Layout/Article_Type1&c=Article&cid=1158184238766&call_pageid=968332188492&col=968793972154|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929152915/http://www.thestar.com/NASApp/cs/ContentServer?pagename=thestar%2FLayout%2FArticle_Type1&c=Article&cid=1158184238766&call_pageid=968332188492&col=968793972154|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2007-09-29|accessdate=2006-09-14|df=}} scheduled to open its doors at 11:00 a.m. and remain open until 7:00 p.m. and have an "Open House" feel to the day. Classes were scheduled to resume as usual on Tuesday, September 19, 2006. During a police search at Gill's home, an apology note to his family was found. In addition, police seized [[firearm]] accessories including holsters and manuals, including those of [[Beretta CX4 Storm|the firearm]] he used during attack; they also found a letter praising the actions of [[Columbine High School massacre|Columbine shooters]] [[Eric Harris and Dylan Klebold]].{{cite news | author = CTV News | title = Details of Kimveer Gill's apology note revealed | url = http://www.ctvnews.ca/servlet/ArticleNews/story/CTVNews/20070320/gill_note_070320/20070320/ | date = 2007-03-20 }} ===Firearms=== Gill was armed with a [[carbine]] [[rifle]],Firearms Reference Table, Policing Support Services, Royal Canadian Mounted Police. Version 4.2 Canadian February 2011 a [[Glock]] [[pistol]], and a [[shotgun]]. He fired sixty shots, ten of which were fired outside the school. With the exception of five shots from his pistol, including the one to kill himself, all the shots came from the rifle.{{cite news|title=Gun club opened door to Gill, Fabrikant|work=[[The Gazette (Montreal)|The Gazette]]|date=2006-09-15|url=http://www.canada.com/montrealgazette/story.html?id=1d0f80b2-abf1-456b-bc09-3392d71ecb4b|accessdate=2006-09-16|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071103113915/http://www.canada.com/montrealgazette/story.html?id=1d0f80b2-abf1-456b-bc09-3392d71ecb4b|archivedate=2007-11-03|df=}} There were reports of an additional firearm in a bag that he forced a hostage to bring along as he arrived near the campus site. According to TVA's crime reporter [[Claude Poirier]], Gill briefly held a lawyer hostage and demanded that he bring the bag containing the fourth gun and additional [[ammunition]]. When the first shots were fired and police arrived, the lawyer fled the scene and hid Gill's bag. Gill had a restricted firearm license. His firearms were registered with the [[Canadian gun registry]]. The transportation, storage, and use of his firearms in the incident were not legal as per [[Gun politics in Canada]], despite the acquisition and possession being legal. ===Victims=== [[File:15-09-06 1407.jpg|thumb|right|Two days after the event, people bring flowers to the de Maisonneuve entrance, where the first shots had been fired.]] The police confirmed the death of one victim, an 18-year-old woman who was shot in the abdomen and died on the scene. Canadian newspapers later identified the woman as Anastasia Rebecca De Sousa.{{cite news |url = http://www.canada.com/montrealgazette/news/story.html?id=1dc31f5a-940d-4147-b5c7-d693b38f4f35&k=66350 |title = Dawson College victim succumbs to injuries |date = 2006-09-14 |accessdate = 2006-09-14 |publisher = Montreal Gazette |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070406015622/http://www.canada.com/montrealgazette/news/story.html?id=1dc31f5a-940d-4147-b5c7-d693b38f4f35&k=66350 |archivedate = 2007-04-06 |df = }} The [[Service de police de la Ville de Montréal|Montreal Police Service]] later reported that 19 other people had been wounded. One victim, who was reportedly at Dawson College to visit friends, suffered two shots to the head. He underwent intensive surgery; the doctors removed one bullet, and he remained in a coma for one week after the shooting as doctors determined whether they should try to remove the second bullet.{{cite news |url=http://www.cjnews.com/viewarticle.asp?id=10188 |title=Jewish student in critical condition |author=David Lazarus |date=2006-09-20 |accessdate=2006-09-21 |publisher=Canadian Jewish News}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} After two weeks on a ventilator, he emerged from the coma and {{As of|2006|11|03|lc=yes}} was recovering.{{cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/montreal/dawson-college-shooting-victim-making-miraculous-recovery-1.599516 |title=Dawson College shooting victim making 'miraculous' recovery |publisher=CBC news |date=2006-11-03 |accessdate=2015-12-06 }} ==Perpetrator== {{Main|Kimveer Gill}} Gill was a 25-year-old Canadian born in [[Lachine, Quebec]], Canada. His parents were of [[Punjabi people|Punjabi]] descent, and moved to [[Saint-Laurent, Quebec]] from India in early 1981.Montreal Gazette, Sue Montgomerey [http://www.canada.com/montrealgazette/story.html?id=b80740cf-e43e-411d-a131-b07ebaa8335b "Who was Kimveer Gill?" ] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140816034421/http://www.canada.com/montrealgazette/story.html?id=b80740cf-e43e-411d-a131-b07ebaa8335b |date=2014-08-16 }} /www.Canada.com/montrealgazette The family later settled in the [[Fabreville]] area of Laval, Quebec in 1987. Kimveer attended Twin Oaks Elementary School in Laval from 1988 to 1993. Gill later attended [[Rosemere High School]], where he was remembered by teachers as quiet and unassuming. Despite early media reports, he performed well academically, and most students remember him as having friends and certainly never being bullied.{{cite news|url=http://www.canada.com/montrealgazette/story.html?id=d1933b65-8a0c-454f-bff0-9e072f8918b5&p=1|title=Who Was Kimveer Gill? (Part 2)|author=|date=|work=canada.com|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121114120417/http://www.canada.com/montrealgazette/story.html?id=d1933b65-8a0c-454f-bff0-9e072f8918b5&p=1|archivedate=2012-11-14|df=}} Kimveer graduated from Rosemere High School in June 1998. He enrolled in [[Vanier College]] with his friend Steven Kulczycki after graduation; however, he dropped out in January 1999. Gill briefly received military training from the [[Canadian Forces Leadership and Recruit School]] in [[Saint-Jean-sur-Richelieu]], [[Quebec]], from January 17 to February 16, 1999. He had told his friends he wished to eventually become a [[mercenary]]. He did not complete his basic training for unknown reasons. He was deemed unsuitable for military service and was voluntarily discharged before receiving extensive weapons training. Gill was a member of a rifle club and visited the Ville Saint-Pierre facility the day prior to the shooting.{{cite news|url=http://www.tvanouvelles.ca/2006/09/16/les-parents-du-tireur-se-confient|title=Les parents du tireur se confient|work=TVA Nouvelles|date=16 September 2006|accessdate=21 March 2016|language=fr}} [http://www.canada.com/reginaleaderpost/news/canada_world/story.html?id=b3472ac0-b095-40b6-84f4-8b4e69d0930b Killer's Mom Noticed Change In Son's Mood] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160117143059/http://www.canada.com/reginaleaderpost/news/canada_world/story.html?id=b3472ac0-b095-40b6-84f4-8b4e69d0930b |date=2016-01-17 }} September 16, 2006 report by CanWest news wire reporter Sue Montgomery, accessed online at [[Leader-Post]] website September 20, 2006. Police initially looked for as many as three suspects, but Montreal Police Chief Yvan Delorme later confirmed that there was only one shooter, who was shot and killed on the scene. Many eyewitnesses described a man with a [[Mohawk hairstyle]], wearing a black [[trenchcoat]],{{cite news|last=Moore |first=Dene |author2=Panetta, Alexander |title=Gunman and young woman die in shooting rampage at Montreal college |work=[[CFTR (AM)|680 News]] |date=2006-09-13 |url=http://www.680news.com/news/national/article.jsp?content=n0913123A |accessdate=2006-09-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927041521/http://www.680news.com/news/national/article.jsp?content=n0913123A |archivedate=September 27, 2007 }} black trousers with metal studs, and combat boots. The suspect carried three weapons, including a semi-automatic carbine.{{cite news|author=[[CTV Television Network|CTV]].ca Staff|title=Student killed in Montreal shooting rampage|work=[[CTV Television Network|CTV]].ca|date=2006-09-13|url=http://www.ctv.ca/servlet/ArticleNews/story/CTVNews/20060913/montreal_shooting_060913/20060913|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110629085116/http://www.ctv.ca/CTVNews/TopStories/20060913/montreal_shooting_060913/|archivedate=2011-06-29|accessdate=2006-09-13}} That evening, a [[Sûreté du Québec]] spokesperson confirmed to [[Le Canal Nouvelles|LCN TV]] reporters that the shooter was a 25-year-old male, born in Québec.{{cite news|url=http://www.iht.com/articles/2006/09/14/america/web.0914montreal.php|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090204004759/http://www.iht.com/articles/2006/09/14/america/web.0914montreal.php|archivedate=2009-02-04|title=Montreal campus gunman is identified|date=2006-09-14|accessdate=2006-09-14|publisher=International Herald Tribune}} Police found his car, a black [[Pontiac Sunfire]], parked close to the school, and later searched the house where he lived with his mother, seizing a computer and other belongings.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/5350042.stm|title=Canada gun victims still critical|date=2006-09-15|accessdate=2006-09-15|publisher=BBC World News}} Around midnight on Wednesday, police confirmed to the media that the suspect was Kimveer Gill, a 25-year-old [[Laval, Quebec|Laval]] resident, a graduate from [[Rosemere High School]].{{cite news|last=Picard|first=André|title=Carnage and courage in Montreal|work=[[The Globe and Mail]]|date=2006-09-14|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20060914.wshootmain14/BNStory/National/home|accessdate=2006-09-13}}{{dead link|date=January 2013}} An autopsy later revealed that Gill committed suicide after being hit in the arm by police officer Denis Côté's gunfire.{{cite news|title=Le tireur s'est suicidé|work=Radio-Canada|date=2006-09-14|url=http://www.radio-canada.ca/nouvelles/societe/2006/09/14/018-gill-suicide.shtml|accessdate=2006-09-14|language=French}} It was also revealed that the shooting was premeditated, as a short suicide note was then found on Gill's body. The killer's profile was discovered on a website called [[Vampirefreaks.com|VampireFreaks]] under the screen name "fatality666." The last login was at 10:35 a.m. on the day of the shooting.[https://web.archive.org/web/20070325020518/http://www.thestar.com/NASApp/cs/ContentServer?pagename=thestar%2FLayout%2FArticle_Type1&c=Article&cid=1158184238759&call_pageid=968332188492&col=968793972154&t=TS_Home Killer loved guns, hated people] ''The Star'' 2006-9-14 The profile was subsequently restricted to registered users, and then removed entirely. The television network [[TVA (Canada)|TVA]] reported that [[security camera]] footage from [[Place Alexis Nihon]] showed Gill staking out the area as far back as August 10, more than a month before the shootings.{{cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/Page/document/v5/content/subscribe?user_URL=https://www.theglobeandmail.com%2Fservlet%2Fstory%2FRTGAM.20060915.wxshooting-gill16%2FBNStory%2FNational%2Fhome%20theglobeandmail.com&ord=972045&brand=theglobeandmail&force_login=true|title=Shooter had brief military service|accessdate=2007-08-05|author=Tu Thanh Ha|author2=Ingrid Peritz|author3=Andre Picard|date=2006-09-16|publisher=The Globe and Mail|df=}}{{dead link|date=October 2017|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} == Response == === Students and faculty === Some student leaders criticized the immediate response of the Dawson College administration. ''The Chronicle of Higher Education'' reported that "if it hadn't been for help from the Student Union at nearby Concordia University... many of the Dawson students would have had no one to turn to for help."{{cite web|url=http://chronicle.com/daily/2006/09/2006091502n.htm |title=A Day After Rampage at Montreal College, Dark Details of the Gunman Emerge |accessdate=2006-08-25 |last=Payne |first=Doug |date=2006-09-15 |publisher=The Chronicle of Higher Education |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080606071710/http://chronicle.com/daily/2006/09/2006091502n.htm |archivedate=June 6, 2008 }} Dawson's director-general Richard Filion called the student charges harsh. "We did our best to evacuate the building. We were in a state of shock. We were scattered everywhere around the city," Filion said, noting many staff members were out on lunch break. Dawson does have an emergency plan, he said, but it was designed with fire safety in mind.PEGGY CURRAN, MARISSA LAROUCHE-SMART and BRENDA BRANSWELL. "A long journey back from tears: :[Final Edition]. " The Gazette [Montreal, Que.] 15 Sep. 2006, A3. Canadian Newsstand Major Dailies. ProQuest. Dawson College Lib, Westmount, QC. 23 Apr. 2008 {{cite web |url=http://www.canada.com/story.html?id=655d71d0-1525-4c50-b016-02d02048afd0 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-03-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160404161644/http://www.canada.com/story.html?id=655d71d0-1525-4c50-b016-02d02048afd0 |archivedate=2016-04-04 |df= }} Filion announced that staff and faculty would return to the College on Friday, September 15, and that classes would resume on Tuesday, September 19, 2006. The school invited all students to join them on Monday, September 18, 2006 to meet with staff and faculty for information and support, as well as to retrieve belongings that had been left behind. It was announced that grief counseling and support services would be available on an ongoing basis. In addition, one of the victims, 18-year-old Hayder Kadhim, who received two bullet wounds to the head and neck, challenged Prime Minister [[Stephen Harper]] to a gun control debate in a public speech on CBC in response to the shooting.{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/montreal/story/2006/11/01/kadhim-guncontrolcampaign.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061103043403/http://www.cbc.ca/canada/montreal/story/2006/11/01/kadhim-guncontrolcampaign.html|title=Dawson shooting victim launches national gun control campaign|archivedate=3 November 2006|publisher=CBC|accessdate=2006-11-01| date = 1 November 2006}} === Politicians === * [[Prime Minister of Canada|Canadian Prime Minister]] [[Stephen Harper]] stated the shootings were "...a cowardly and senseless act of violence..."{{cite news|title=Prime Minister Stephen Harper conveys sympathy to Dawson College victims|url=http://www.canada.com/globaltv/national/story.html?id=aed86776-3a28-4470-a4cf-693cc099d5de|work=[[Canadian Press]]|publisher=[[Global National]]|date=2006-09-13|accessdate=2006-09-13|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061021021354/http://www.canada.com/globaltv/national/story.html?id=aed86776-3a28-4470-a4cf-693cc099d5de|archivedate=2006-10-21|df=}}{{cite news|title=Politicians express sorrow over college shootings|url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/2006/09/13/political-reaction-shootings.html|work=[[CBC News]]|date=2006-09-14|accessdate=2006-09-15}} * Interim [[Liberal Party of Canada|Liberal Party]] leader [[Bill Graham (Canadian politician)|Bill Graham]] and [[Member of Parliament]] (MP) [[Lucienne Robillard]]: "We must act as a country to show our compassion for those whose lives have been dramatically altered by this inexplicable event." * [[Bloc Québécois]] Leader [[Gilles Duceppe]]: "It's tragic. We can never explain why these things happen. At the [[École Polytechnique massacre|Polytechnique]] women were targeted. But here, we have no idea." Duceppe also suggested the need for a national gun registry. * [[New Democratic Party of Canada|New Democratic Party]] Leader [[Jack Layton]] mentioned that it "was a grim reminder of previous school shootings" and that it hit particularly close to home for him; Layton was born and raised in a suburb of Montreal and attended [[McGill University]], a short distance from Dawson College. * [[Quebec Premier]] [[Jean Charest]] stated "We are deeply saddened for the victims, the families, the parents of the children who study at Dawson." *Montreal Mayor [[Gérald Tremblay]] stated "This is so tragic. How do we talk to the parents who are going through this? All I can say is that I feel for them, and I care for them." === Video gaming community === * [[Danny Ledonne]], creator of [[Super Columbine Massacre RPG!]], expressed his sorrow{{cite web |url=http://www.columbinegame.com/DawsonCollege.htm |title=Dawson College Statement |accessdate=2007-08-06| author=Danny Ledonne}} at the shootings, asked members of his web site to "... be aware of the sensitive nature of Montreal right now and of those who were affected by this shooting," and explained how his game is not designed to train shooters.{{cite web |url=http://kotaku.com/201829/feature-columbine-rpg-creator-talks-about-dawson-shooting?tag=gamingdannyledonne |title=Feature Columbine RPG Creator Talks About Dawson Shooting |accessdate=2007-08-06 |author=Brian Crecente |publisher= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120612011242/http://kotaku.com/201829/feature-columbine-rpg-creator-talks-about-dawson-shooting?tag=gamingdannyledonne |archivedate=2012-06-12 |df= }} * [[Ian Bogost]] of Water Cooler Games{{cite web |url=http://kotaku.com/201989/bogost-talks-about-dawson-shooting?tag=gamingianbogost |title=Bogost Talks About Dawson Shooting |accessdate=2007-08-06 |author= |publisher= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121015054743/http://kotaku.com/201989/bogost-talks-about-dawson-shooting?tag=gamingianbogost |archivedate=2012-10-15 |df= }} says "A tragedy like this saddens and disturbs us all... Gill was a disturbed man [...] he clearly needed help he did not get." === Complaints about media coverage === ====Jan Wong controversy==== An immediate controversy arose about an article regarding the Dawson shootings by journalist [[Jan Wong]], of the [[Toronto|Toronto-based]] ''[[The Globe and Mail]]''. Three days after the event, Wong, who was born and raised in Montreal and is the daughter of [[China|Chinese]] immigrants, wrote a front-page piece titled ''Get under the desk'', in which she drew a link between all three school shootings in Quebec history (the [[École Polytechnique massacre|École Polytechnique]], the [[Concordia University massacre|Concordia University]] and the Dawson College killings) and the nature of Quebec society under its protective [[Charter of the French Language|language laws]].{{cite news |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/LAC.20060916.SHOOTMAIN16/TPStory/TPNational/ |archive-url=https://archive.is/20070313143539/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/LAC.20060916.SHOOTMAIN16/TPStory/TPNational/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2007-03-13 |title=Get under the desk |accessdate=2007-08-05| author=Jan Wong |date=2006-09-16|publisher=The Globe and Mail}} Wong suggested the fact that the three perpetrators were not old-stock French Quebecers (the shooters were Algerian, Belarusian, and Indian in descent) was related to their murderous actions since, she claimed, they were alienated from a Quebec society concerned with "[[racial purity]]." Accused of "[[Quebec bashing]]," Wong's writing soon created public outcry in Quebec and political condemnation. Quebec Premier [[Jean Charest]] called the article a "disgrace", stating that it "betrays an ignorance of Canadian values and a profound misunderstanding of Québec."{{cite news |url=http://www.canada.com/montrealgazette/story.html?id=7558331f-14b9-4b1a-bfc1-e5a68dbe3999&k=47772 |title=Charest blasts Toronto reporter |author=Jean Charest |date=2006-09-19 |accessdate=2006-09-21 |publisher=Montreal Gazette |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121023005926/http://www.canada.com/montrealgazette/story.html?id=7558331f-14b9-4b1a-bfc1-e5a68dbe3999&k=47772 |archivedate=2012-10-23 |df= }} On September 20, 2006, Prime Minister [[Stephen Harper]] pronounced it "prejudiced, absurd, irresponsible and without foundation";{{cite news |url=http://www.ctv.ca/servlet/ArticleNews/story/CTVNews/20060920/janwon_column_060920/20060920?hub=Canada |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110629072750/http://www.ctv.ca/CTVNews/Canada/20060920/janwon_column_060920/ |archivedate=2011-06-29 |title=Harper complains to Globe about Jan Wong column |date=2006-09-20 |accessdate=2006-09-21 |publisher=CTV Canada}} the same day, the [[House of Commons of Canada]] unanimously passed a motion requesting an apology for the column.{{cite web |url=http://www.parl.gc.ca/HousePublications/Publication.aspx?Language=E&Mode=1&Parl=39&Ses=1&DocId=2343366 |title=39th Parliament, 1st Session, Number 049 |date=2006-09-20 |accessdate=2006-09-21 |work=House of Commons Debates |publisher=Parliament of Canada}} Wong's writing followed the comments of Professor [[Elliott Leyton]], a [[Anthropology|social-anthropologist]] who is a widely consulted expert on [[Serial killer|serial homicide]].{{cite web |url=http://www.ctv.ca/servlet/ArticleNews/story/CTVNews/1123592030758_54 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050811010344/http://www.ctv.ca/servlet/ArticleNews/story/CTVNews/1123592030758_54 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2005-08-11 |title=''Looking into the minds of serial murderers '' |date=2005-08-09 |accessdate=2005-09-09 |publisher=CTV NEWS |df= }} Interviewed by [[CBC Newsworld]] on September 14, 2006 about the Dawson College shooting, Leyton stated that because all three such murderous rampages in [[Quebec]] involved a killer who was either an [[immigrant]] or a child of immigrants, it warranted an examination of government and societal attitudes. ====Broadcast Code violation==== In 2007, the [[Canadian Broadcast Standards Council]] faulted [[CKNW (AM)|CKNW]], a radio station in [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]] for airing "potentially dangerous information" during the Dawson College shooting. During the incident, CKNW had [[simulcast]] content from its sister stations in Montreal which included students speaking by cellphone from inside the school. A Vancouver man complained that the content could have told the gunman where the students were. The council said that as a result of modern technology reducing geographic distance as a barrier, CKNW had breached Section 10 (coverage of violent situations) of the broadcast code. The station broadcast the decision as required, but did not air an apology.{{Cite news | last=Eustance | first=Chantal | title=CKNW report on college shootings breached code | newspaper=The [[Vancouver Sun]] | publication-place=Vancouver, BC | date=July 21, 2007 | url= | postscript= }} ===Megadeth=== Gill mentioned the song "[[À Tout le Monde]]" by the [[thrash metal]] band [[Megadeth]] on his blog on VampireFreaks.com on the day of the shooting. Megadeth was blamed for the shooting by many news outlets and watchdog groups as a result. Later in 2006, Megadeth performed live in Montreal, and responded to the blame that had been placed on the band and their music as a result. Band leader [[Dave Mustaine]] told the crowd:
The guy who went to Dawson College and shot everyone, it's terrible. Aside from the fact that what he did was wrong, we have a relationship with Montreal, and that really pissed us off.
Before the concert in an interview for CBC News Mustaine said:
"I was so angry that this guy would use my song, and that he would try and turn that beautiful song into something ugly and nasty. It's for those who lost their lives, and it's a gift to those who are in the process of healing (...) and Gill was not worthy of being a Megadeth fan."{{cite web|url=http://www.chartattack.com/news/2006/09/29/megadeth-criticize-fan-who-shot-up-dawson-college/|title=Megadeth Criticize Fan Who Shot Up Dawson College|author=|date=|work=Chart Attack|access-date=2013-12-28|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131231001732/http://www.chartattack.com/news/2006/09/29/megadeth-criticize-fan-who-shot-up-dawson-college/|archive-date=2013-12-31|dead-url=yes|df=}}
===''Natural Born Killers''=== {{See also|Natural Born Killers copycat crimes#Dawson College shooting}} This is the ninth mass killing{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2002/dec/20/artsfeatures1|title=Natural born copycats|author=Xan Brooks|date=|work=the Guardian}} to implicate the movie ''[[Natural Born Killers]]'', per the gunman's blog at vampirefreaks.com, which he called one of his favourites. At some point prior to September 20, 2006, the blog was deleted. ==Long-term effects== A follow-up study conducted by the McGill University Health Centre Research Institute found that 30% of Dawson students at the time of the shooting suffered mental health consequences including [[post-traumatic stress disorder]], major [[Major depressive disorder|depression]], [[alcohol dependence]], and [[social phobia]], a level twice that found in the general population. Approximately 18% of respondents developed a mental health disorder despite never having had one before.Branswell, Brenda. '''Footsteps''' is a not-for-profit organization based in [[New York City]] that provides educational, vocational, and social support to people who have left or want to [[Yetzia bish'eila|leave an ultra-Orthodox]] or [[Orthodox Jewish]] community in the United States.<ref>[[Ari Shapiro]]. [https://www.npr.org/2011/08/08/139220021/leaving-the-fold Young Ultra-Orthodox Jews Struggle Against Tradition], ''[[All Things Considered]]'', August 8, 2011.</ref>
== Mission == According to its website, Footsteps provides educational, vocational, professional, social, and legal support to those seeking to enter or explore the world beyond the insular ultra-religious communities in which they were raised. Some people from the ultra-orthodox and Chasidic communities who choose to enter mainstream America may feel like cultural immigrants. They may face cultural disorientation and isolation coupled with a lack of practical and marketable skills. Founded in December 2003, Footsteps aims to assist individuals who choose to make this difficult transition. Individuals frequently refer to themselves as “[[off the derech]]”, or OTD, reclaiming the dismissive term given to leavers by members of the orthodox communities they have left.<ref name="newyorker2017">{{cite web|last1=Lavin|first1=Talia|title=Off the Path of Orthodoxy|url=https://www.newyorker.com/news/news-desk/off-the-path-of-orthodoxy|website=New Yorker|accessdate=7 October 2017}}</ref><ref name=nyt2017/>
== History == Footsteps was founded in December, 2003, by Malkie Schwartz, a former [[Chabad]] Hasid from [[Crown Heights, Brooklyn|Crown Heights]], while enrolled as a student at [[Hunter College]] in New York City. According to Schwartz, 20 people showed up to the first meeting, announced on flyers around the Hunter campus and through word of mouth.<ref name="unp">Orli Santo. [http://www.unpious.com/2010/08/the-departed/ The Departed], ''Unpious.com'', August 17, 2010.</ref> Footsteps began as an informal social group and soon developed an [[General Educational Development|educational study]] group and a [[Sex education in the United States|sex education]] and relationships group, members finding they had been denied access to basic sex education instruction within the ultra-orthodox community.
As the organization grew it became a [[501(c)(3) organization|501(c) non profit]] with a broad remit of support and education for ex-ultra orthodox Jewish individuals and their families.<ref name="nyt2017">{{cite web|last1=Brodesser-Akner|first1=Taffy|authorlink=Taffy Brodesser-Akner|title=The High Price of Leaving Ultra-Orthodox Life|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/30/magazine/the-high-price-of-leaving-ultra-orthodox-life.html|website=New York Times|accessdate=7 October 2017}}</ref> Footsteps can also provide counseling and has partnered with [[New York Legal Assistance Group]] to provide legal assistance and advice in divorce and custody cases.<ref name=jw2017/>
As of summer 2015 Footsteps has a permanent staff of 10, a membership of over 1000 and an annual budget in excess of $1 million.<ref name="jw2017">{{cite web|last1=Clark|first1=Amy Sara|title=Lani Santo, 35|url=http://jewishweek.timesofisrael.com/lani-santo-35/|website=Jewish Week|publisher=Times of Israel|accessdate=7 October 2017}}</ref> Its current director is Lani Santo.<ref name=newyorker2017/> The organization's program director is [[Chani Getter]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/05/25/nyregion/orthodox-jewish-divorce-custody-ny.html|title=When Living Your Truth Can Mean Losing Your Children|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wsj.com/articles/formerly-orthodox-and-struggling-for-parental-rights-1407810872|title=Formerly Orthodox, and Struggling for Parental Rights|first=Melanie Grayce|last=West|date=12 August 2014|publisher=|via=www.wsj.com}}</ref>
== Activities == [[File:Muslimish & Footsteps.webm|thumb|[[Muslimish]]' ex-Muslims president Noura Embabi explains how they cooperate with Footsteps' formerly Orthodox Jews.]] Footsteps provides an array of services for its members. The Footsteps offices are known as "The Space" and are situated at an unpublicized location due to privacy concerns,<ref name="gua2017">{{cite web|last1=Halime|first1=Farah|title=Life after conservative faith: the defectors who leave ultra-Orthodox communities|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/mar/27/ultra-orthodox-judaism-defectors-new-york|website=The Guardian|accessdate=7 October 2017}}</ref> contains a computer lab, library, meeting space, kitchenette, and lounge, where members can work and hang out. Members gather for various groups, events, and workshops on topics including dating and sexuality, navigating the college admissions process, career advancement and painting.<ref>[[Libby Copeland]]. [http://www.slate.com/articles/double_x/doublex/2012/08/hasidic_jews_and_the_internet_a_bad_combination_.single.html Google vs. God: What’s causing all these Hasidic Jews to flee their community? Smartphones], ''Slate.com'', August 21, 2012.</ref>
Footsteps also holds several annual events, which are open to members and guests. Events include: Thanksgiving dinner, Passover Potluck, and an annual camping trip. Since 2009, "Footsteps Celebrates" has been held each year in June, to celebrate graduations, accomplishments, and leadership roles.<ref name="fsc">Josh Nathan-Kazis. [http://blogs.forward.com/forward-thinking/157558/the-footsteps-of-those-leaving-ultra-orthodoxy/ The 'Footsteps' of Those Leaving Ultra-Orthodoxy], ''Forward.com'', June 8, 2012.</ref> During summer months, Footsteps organizes a weekly soccer game in Prospect Park. During winter, an indoor game of basketball takes place bi-weekly.<ref name="fwd">Josh Nathan-Kazis. [http://forward.com/articles/158212/for-ex-orthodox-more-than-a-game/ For Ex-Orthodox, More Than a Game], ''Forward.com'', June 29, 2012.</ref>
Footsteps has also holds annual art shows in which it exhibits works by Footsteps members.<ref name="fwdart">[[Shulem Deen]]. [http://blogs.forward.com/the-arty-semite/137264/ex-haredi-artists-grapple-with-their-pasts/ Ex-Haredi Artists Grapple With Their Pasts], ''Forward.com'', April 27, 2011.</ref>
== Leadership == Board members include author [[Shulem Deen]] and businessman [[Steve Eisman]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Board of directors|url=https://www.footstepsorg.org/board-of-directors/|website=Footsteps.org|accessdate=7 October 2017}}</ref>
==Coverage== Footsteps has been featured in numerous media outlets, including The New York Times, The Wall Street Journal, The Guardian, PBS, NBC, and many others. The book ''Unchosen: The Hidden Lives of Hasidic Rebels'' by Hella Winston relates the story of the founder of Footsteps and some of those who have gone through the organization as part of their journey to leave the ultra-Orthodox and Orthodox community. The [[National Geographic Channel|National Geographic]] program, "Inside Hasidism," included a segment about Footsteps and some of its members.<ref name="natgeo">{{cite web| title=Inside Hasidism| publisher=Fox International Channels| accessdate=2015-05-31| url=http://ficcontentsales.com/programmes/main.aspx?id=1267}}</ref>
== See also == *[[Faith to Faithless]] *[[Religious disaffiliation]] *[[Leaving Ultra-Orthodox Judaism]] *[[Off the derech]] *[[Mavar]], a UK-based organization which supports the transition of leaving the Haredi lifestyle in Britain.
== Notable members == * [[Leah Vincent]], author. * [[Shulem Deen]], author. * [[Luzer Twersky]], actor and model. * [[Abby Stein]], writer and trans activist. * [[Naftuli Moster]], founder and CEO of [[YAFFED]].

{{Infobox artist | honorific_prefix = | name = Gay Block<!-- include middle initial, if not specified in birth_name --> | honorific_suffix = | image = <!-- just the pagename, without the File:/Image: prefix or [[brackets]] --> | image_size = | alt = | caption = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | birth_name = <!--only use if different from name--> | birth_date = 1942<!-- {{Birth date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} for living artists, {{Birth date|YYYY|MM|DD}} for dead --> | birth_place = [[Houston, Texas]] | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | death_place = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline}} --> | nationality = American | education = | alma_mater = | known_for = | notable_works = | style = | movement = | spouse = Billie Parker | awards = <!-- {{awd|award|year|title|role|name}} (optional) --> | elected = | patrons = | memorials = | website = <!-- {{URL|Example.com}} --> | module = }} '''Gay Block''' (born 1942) is a [[fine art]] [[portrait]] [[photographer]], who was born in [[Houston, Texas]].<ref>[http://www.nyartbeat.com/event/2013/BABA "Gay Block "Love: South Beach in the 80's"], NY Art Beat. Retrieved 31 March 2013.</ref> Her work is shown in books, and is collected by the [[Museum of Modern Art]], [[San Francisco Museum of Modern Art]], the [[Museum of Fine Arts, Houston]], the [[El Paso Museum of Art]]<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.gayblock.com/exhib.html|title = Gay Block CV|date = |accessdate = 13 March 2015|website = Gay Block|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> and the [[New Mexico Museum of Art]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sam.nmartmuseum.org/view/objects/asimages/People$00404124?t:state:flow=b238d1c4-ae31-46d9-9674-313a8f9d97b2|publisher=New Mexico Museum of Art|accessdate=27 December 2013|title = SAM: Searchable Art Museum|date = 2010}}</ref>
== Biography == Block had been interested in photography since she was a pre-teen, when she started taking pictures of her friends and family using a [[Brownie (camera)|Brownie]] box camera.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title = Texas 100: Selections from the El Paso Museum of Art|last = |first = |publisher = El Paso Museum of Art Foundation|year = 2006|isbn = 0978538307|location = El Paso, Texas|pages = 23|editor-last = Dura|editor-first = Lucia}}</ref> She recalls that she enjoyed taking candid photos and collaborating with her subjects.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = http://www.gayblock.com/the.html|title = The Universe of Gay Block|last = Block|first = Gay|date = October 2003|journal = THE Magazine|doi = |pmid = |access-date = 13 March 2015}}</ref>
By the 1970s she began taking pictures of members of her own affluent [[Jewish]] community in Houston.<ref name=":0" /> She later photographed an older Jewish Community of [[retirees]] in [[South Beach|South Miami Beach]], many of whom were [[Holocaust survivor]]s. Block also photographed girls at [[summer camp]]. In 2006, Block re-photographed women who were the girls in her 1981 series from Camp Pinecliffe, twenty-five years earlier.
Block collaborated with author, Rabbi [[Malka Drucker]], and created ''Rescuers: Portraits of Moral Courage in the Holocaust'', both a book and traveling exhibit.<ref name=":0" /> Block and Drucker traveled to eleven countries and photographed over 100 [[Christian]]s who had helped rescue Jews during the Holocaust.<ref name=":0" /> The exhibit has been seen in over fifty venues in the US and abroad, including the [[Museum of Modern Art]], [[New York City|NY]], in 1992.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.moma.org/exhibitions/1992|title = MoMA Exhibitions|date = 2002|accessdate = 13 March 2015|website = Museum of Modern Art|publisher = |last = |first = |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20030220000742/http://www.moma.org/exhibitions/1992/|archivedate = 20 February 2003}}</ref>
In 2003, Block's 30-year series of portraits of her mother, in photographs, video, and words, ''Bertha Alyce: Mother exPosed'', was published by [[University of New Mexico Press]] and continues as a traveling exhibit. The book, ''Bertha Alyce'', was cited as one of "Twelve Great Books Published During The Year 2003" by the editors of RALPH (The Review of Arts, Literature, Politics, and the Humanities).<ref>{{Cite journal|url = http://www.ralphmag.org/CM/dozen-best.html|title = Twelve Great Books Published During the Year 2003|last = |first = |date = 2004|journal = RALPH: The Review of Arts, Literature, Philosophy and the Humanities|doi = |pmid = |access-date = 13 March 2015|issue = 109|editor-last = Lark|editor-first = Lolita}}</ref> Her video of the material, "Bertha Alyce", was awarded People's Choice and Best Documentary by the Madrid International Gay & Lesbian Film Festival, [[Spain]]. The photographs of Bertha Alyce are not considered a conventional representation of a mother/daughter relationship; instead Block's relationship with her mother is unique.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|url = http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=a9h&AN=12377709&site=ehost-live|title = Gay Block at University of New Mexico Art Museum|last = Reed|first = Arden|date = March 2004|journal = Art in America|doi = |pmid = |access-date = 13 March 2015|volume = 92|issue = 3|page = 136}}</ref> Block's documentary technique is considered by the critic to be "assured, if reminiscent of Duane Michaels or [[Nan Goldin]]."<ref name=":1" />
== Quotes == "My portraits are my truth, not necessarily the truth."<ref>{{Cite journal|url=http://www.wallpaper.com/art/arles-anne-wilkes-tucker/1665 |title=Arles: Anne Wilkes Tucker |last= |first= |date=16 August 2007 |journal=Wallpaper |doi= |pmid= |access-date=13 March 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402093338/http://www.wallpaper.com/art/arles-anne-wilkes-tucker/1665 |archivedate=2 April 2015 |df= }}</ref>
==Exhibitions==
"Rescuers: Portraits of Moral Courage in the Holocaust" Museum of Modern Art, New York. Corcoran Gallery of Art, Washington, DC. Museum of Fine Arts, Houston, TX. University of New Mexico Art Museum, Albuquerque, NM. Houston Center for Photography, Houston, TX. See CV for a complete listing of exhibitions.

[[Image:La salle dAkhenaton (1356-1340 av J.C.) (Musée du Caire) (2076972086).jpg|300px|thumb|Pharaoh [[Akhenaten]] and his family adoring the Aten.]] [[Image:Aten worship - Great Hymn to Aten2.jpg|thumb|Drawing of the inscription of the hymn text (1908 publication).]] '''The Great Hymn to the Aten''' is the longest of one of a number of hymn-poems written to the [[solar deity|sun-disk]] deity [[Aten]]. Composed in the middle of the 14th century BC, it is attributed to the [[18th dynasty]] Pharaoh [[Akhenaten]], who radically changed traditional forms of [[Ancient Egyptian religion|Egyptian religion]] by replacing them with [[Atenism]]. The hymn-poem provides a glimpse of the religious artistry of the [[Atenism|Amarna period]] expressed in multiple forms encompassing literature, new temples, and in the building of a whole new city at the site of present-day Amarna as the capital of Egypt. Egyptologist [[Toby Wilkinson]] said that "It has been called 'one of the most significant and splendid pieces of poetry to survive from the pre-Homeric world.'"{{cite book|last=Wilkinson|first=Toby|title=The Rise and Fall of Ancient Egypt|year=2011|publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing|isbn=978-1408810026|pages=289–290}} Egyptologist John Darnell asserts that the hymn was sung.{{cite book|last=Darnell>[http://www.yale.edu/archaeology/f.johndarnell.html]|first=John|title=Tutankhamun's Armies: Battle and Conquest During Ancient Egypt's Late Eighteenth Dynasty|isbn=978-0471743583|page=41}} Various courtiers' [[rock-cut architecture|rock tombs]] at [[Amarna]] (ancient Akhet-Aten, the city Akhenaten founded) have similar prayers or hymns to the [[ancient Egyptian deities|deity]] Aten or to the Aten and [[Akhenaten]] jointly. One of these, found in almost identical form in five tombs, is known as ''The Short Hymn to the Aten''. The long version discussed in this article was found in the [[Southern Tomb 25|tomb]] of the courtier (and later Pharaoh) [[Ay]].{{cite book|last=Lichtheim|first=Miriam|title=Ancient Egyptian Literature: Volume II: The New Kingdom|year=2006|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=978-0520248434|page=90}} The [[18th dynasty]] Pharaoh Akhenaten forbade the worship of other gods, a radical departure from the centuries of Egyptian religious practice. Finally, Akhenaten issued a royal decree that the name Aten was no longer to be depicted by the hieroglyph of a solar disc emanating rays but instead had to be spelled out phonetically. Akhenaton's religious reforms (later regarded [[heretical]] and reverted under his successor [[Pharaoh]] [[Tutankhamun]]) have been described by some scholars as [[Monotheism|monotheistic]], though others consider it to be [[Henotheism|henotheistic]].{{cite book|last=Brewer|first=Douglas j.|title=Egypt and the Egyptians|year=2 edition (22 Feb 2007)|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-85150-3|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=evudwvrKErEC&pg=PA105&dq=elevation+of+the+king+and+his+queen+Nefertiti#v=onepage&q=elevation%20of%20the%20king%20and%20his%20queen%20Nefertiti&f=false|author2=Emily Teeter|page=105}}Simson Najovits, ''Egypt, the Trunk of the Tree. A Modern Survey of an Ancient Land'', II, New York, 2004, pp. [https://books.google.be/books?id=UrR848g3gp8C&pg=PA132 132]-[https://books.google.be/books?id=UrR848g3gp8C&pg=PA136 136]. ==Excerpts of the hymn-poem to Aten== From the middle of the text: :''How manifold it is, what thou hast made!'' :''They are hidden from the face (of man).'' :''O sole god, like whom there is no other!'' :''Thou didst create the world according to thy desire,'' :''Whilst thou wert alone: All men, cattle, and wild beasts,'' :''Whatever is on earth, going upon (its) feet,'' :''And what is on high, flying with its wings.'' :''The countries of Syria and Nubia, the land of Egypt,'' :''Thou settest every man in his place,'' :''Thou suppliest their necessities:'' :''Everyone has his food, and his time of life is reckoned.'' :''Their tongues are separate in speech,'' :''And their natures as well;'' :''Their skins are distinguished,'' :''As thou distinguishest the foreign peoples.'' :''Thou makest a Nile in the underworld, '' :''Thou bringest forth as thou desirest '' :''To maintain the people (of Egypt)'' :''According as thou madest them for thyself,'' :''The lord of all of them, wearying (himself) with them,'' :''The lord of every land, rising for them,'' :''The Aton of the day, great of majesty.''Pritchard, James B., ed., ''The Ancient Near East – Volume 1: An Anthology of Texts and Pictures'', Princeton, New Jersey: Princeton University Press, 1958, pp. 227-230. From the last part of the text, translated by [[Miriam Lichtheim]]: :''You are in my heart,'' :''There is no other who knows you,'' :''Only your son, [[Akhenaten|Neferkheprure, Sole-one-of-Re [Akhenaten]]],'' :''Whom you have taught your ways and your might.'' :''[Those on] earth come from your hand as you made them.'' :''When you have dawned they live.'' :''When you set they die;'' :''You yourself are lifetime, one lives by you.'' :''All eyes are on [your] beauty until you set.'' :''All labor ceases when you rest in the west;'' :''When you rise you stir [everyone] for the King,'' :''Every leg is on the move since you founded the earth.'' :''You rouse them for your son who came from your body.'' :''The King who lives by Maat, the Lord of the Two Lands,'' :''Neferkheprure, Sole-one-of-Re,'' :''The Son of Re who lives by Maat. the Lord of crowns,'' :''Akhenaten, great in his lifetime;'' :''(And) the great Queen whom he loves, the Lady of the Two Lands,'' :''Nefer-nefru-Aten Nefertiti, living forever.''{{cite book|last=Lichtheim|first=Miriam|title=Ancient Egyptian Literature: Volume II: The New Kingdom|year=2nd Ref. Ed. 2006|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=978-0520248434|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nS-7WUndel4C&pg=PA99&lpg=PA99&dq=There+is+no+other+who+knows+you,+Only+your+son,+Neferkheprure&source=bl&ots=DMDLYjH0rb&sig=dh-VhT8YvdFUP4Pppj2bhylFWSY&hl=en&sa=X&ei=F3UnUIXsEceP0AXptoCoCg&ved=0CDIQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=There%20is%20no%20other%20who%20knows%20you%2C%20Only%20your%20son%2C%20Neferkheprure&f=false|page=99}} ==Analysis== Analyses of the poem are divided between those considering it as a work of literature, and those considering its political and socio-religious intentions. [[James Henry Breasted]] considered Akhenaten to be the first monotheist and scientist in history. In 1899, [[Flinders Petrie]] wrote:
If this were a new religion, invented to satisfy our modern scientific conceptions, we could not find a flaw in the correctness of this view of the energy of the solar system. How much Akhenaten understood, we cannot say, but he certainly bounded forward in his views and symbolism to a position which we cannot logically improve upon at the present day. Not a rag of superstition or of falsity can be found clinging to this new worship evolved out of the old Aton of Heliopolis, the sole Lord of the universe.Sir Flinders Petrie, ''History of Egypt'' (edit. 1899), Vol. II, p. 214.
[[Miriam Lichtheim]] describes the hymn as "a beautiful statement of the doctrine of the One God.".{{cite book|last=Lichtheim|first=Miriam|title=Ancient Egyptian Literature: Volume II: The New Kingdom|year=2nd Ref. Ed. 2006|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=978-0520248434}} In 1913 [[Henry Hall (Egyptologist)|Henry Hall]] contended that the pharaoh was the "first example of the scientific mind."H. R. Hall, ''Ancient History of the Near East'' (1913), p. 599. In his book ''Reflections on the Psalms'', [[C.S. Lewis]] compared the Hymn to the [[Psalms]] of the Judaeo-Christian canon, as did Breasted (who broke them up into stanzas to resemble Western poems).{{cite book|last=Montserrat|first=Dominic|title=Akhenaten: History, Fantasy and Ancient Egypt|year=2002|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-0415301862|page=101}} Miriam Lichtheim commented about an alleged resemblance with [[Psalm 104]] saying that "The resemblances are, however, more likely to be the result of the generic similarity between Egyptian hymns and biblical psalms. A specific literary interdependence is not probable."{{cite book|last=Lichtheim|first=Miriam|title=Ancient Egyptian Literature: Volume II: The New Kingdom|year=2006|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=978-0520248434|page=100}} Biblical scholar [[Mark S. Smith]] has commented that "Despite enduring support for the comparison of the two texts, enthusiasm for even indirect influence has been tempered in recent decades. In some quarters, the argument for any form of influence is simply rejected outright. Still some Egyptologists, such as Jan Assmann and Donald Redford, argue for Egyptian influence on both the [[Amarna correspondence]] (especially in EA 147) and on Psalm 104."{{cite book|last1=Smith|first1=Mark S.|title=God in Translation: Deities in Cross-Cultural Discourse in the Biblical World|date=2010|publisher=William B Eerdmans Publishing|isbn=978-0802864338|page=70|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=yvWlC0kUlkYC&pg=PA70&dq=great+hymn+to+the+aten+psalm+104&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwipybqFofrUAhXmIsAKHR5nByUQ6AEIJDAA#v=onepage&q=great%20hymn%20to%20the%20aten%20psalm%20104&f=false|accessdate=8 July 2017}} Egyptologist [[Dominic Montserrat]] discusses the terminology used to describe these texts, describing them as formal poems or royal eulogies. He views the word 'hymn' as suggesting "outpourings of emotion" while he sees them as "eulogies, formal and rhetorical statements of praise" honoring Aten and the royal couple. He credits [[James Henry Breasted]] with the popularisation of them as hymns saying that Breasted (erroneously) saw them as "a gospel of the beauty and beneficence of the natural order, a recognition of the message of nature to the soul of man"(quote from Breasted).{{cite book|last=Montserrat|first=Dominic|title=Akhenaten: History, Fantasy and Ancient Egypt|year=2002|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-0415301862|page=38}} Montserrat argues that all the versions of the hymns focus on the king and suggests that the real innovation is to redefine the relationship of god and king in a way that benefited Akhenaten, quoting the statement of Egyptologist [[John Baines (Egyptologist)|John Baines]] that "Amarna religion was a religion of god and king, or even of king first and then god."{{cite book|last=Montserrat|first=Dominic|title=Akhenaten: History, Fantasy and Ancient Egypt|year=2002|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-0415301862|page=40}}{{cite book|title=Amenhotep III: Perspectives on His Reign|year=1998|publisher=University of Michigan Press|author=John Baines|editors=David O'Connor, Eric Cline|page=281|chapter=The Dawn of the Amarna Age}} [[Donald B. Redford]] argued that while Akhenaten called himself the son of the Sun-Disc and acted as the chief mediator between god and creation, kings for thousands of years before Akhenaten's time had claimed the same relationship and priestly role. However Akhenaten's case may be different through the emphasis placed on the heavenly father and son relationship. Akhenaten described himself as "thy son who came forth from thy limbs", "thy child", "the eternal son that came forth from the Sun-Disc", and "thine only son that came forth from thy body". The close relationship between father and son is such that only the king truly knows the heart of "his father", and in return his father listens to his son's prayers. He is his father's image on earth and as Akhenaten is king on earth his father is king in heaven. As high priest, prophet, king and divine he claimed the central position in the new religious system. Since only he knew his father's mind and will, Akhenaten alone could interpret that will for all mankind with true teaching coming only from him."The Monotheism of the Heretic Pharaoh: Precursor of Mosiac monotheism or Egyptian anomaly?", [[Donald B. Redford]], ''Biblical Archaeology Review'', May–June edition 1987 Redford concluded:
Before much of the archaeological evidence from Thebes and from Tell el-Amarna became available, wishful thinking sometimes turned Akhenaten into a humane teacher of the true God, a mentor of Moses, a Christlike figure, a philosopher before his time. But these imaginary creatures are now fading away one by one as the historical reality gradually emerges. There is little or no evidence to support the notion that Akhenaten was a progenitor of the full-blown monotheism that we find in the Bible. The monotheism of the Hebrew Bible and the New Testament had its own separate development—one that began more than half a millennium after the pharaoh's death."Aspects of Monotheism", Donald B. Redford, ''Biblical Archaeology Review'', 1996

'''Embroidery''' was [[Islamic art|an important art]] in the [[Islamic world]] from the beginning of [[Islam]] until the [[Industrial Revolution]] disrupted traditional ways of life.
==Overview== [[File:Morocco Fez Embroidery Horse Cover.JPG|thumb|left|[[Fly mask]] embroidered with silver thread. [[Fez, Morocco]]. 18th–19th century]]
Early Islam took over societies where the [[embroidery]] of clothes for both sexes and other textiles was very popular. Both the [[Byzantine]] and Persian [[Sasanian]] empires used clothing embroidered with designs including rather large human figures as well as animals, with effects comparable to those of modern [[teeshirt]]s. The exterior of the [[Kaaba]] in [[Mecca]] was already before Islam "covered on the outside with multi-coloured textile hangings",<ref>Ettinghausen, 20</ref> very likely including embroidery as their modern Islamic equivalents often have. [[Muhammad]] objected to animal designs, perhaps embroidered, he saw on cushions when visiting his wife [[Aisha]]'s house.{{efn|Aisha reported in a [[hadith]] "I bought a cushion having on it pictures (of animals). When [[Allah]]'s Apostle saw it, he stood at the door and did not enter. I noticed the sign of disapproval on his face and said, "O Allah's Apostle! I repent to Allah and His Apostle. What [[Islamic views on sin|sin]] have I committed?' Allah's Apostle said. "What is this cushion?" I said, "I have bought it for you so that you may sit on it and recline on it." Allah's Apostle said, "The makers of these pictures will be punished on the [[Islamic eschatology|Day of Resurrection]], and it will be said to them, 'Give life to what you have created (i.e., these pictures).' " The Prophet added, "The Angels of (Mercy) do not enter a house in which there are pictures (of animals)." [[Muhammad al-Bukhari]]<ref>''[[Sahih al-Bukhari]]'' {{Hadith-usc|Bukhari|usc=yes|3|34|318}}, {{Hadith-usc|Bukhari|usc=yes-usc|7|62|110}}</ref>}} These types of design largely disappeared under Islam, though plant-based motifs often remained acceptable.
The 17th century [[Turkish people|Turkish]] traveller [[Evliya Çelebi]] called embroidery the "craft of the two hands".<ref name=Stone/> Because it was a sign of high social status in Muslim societies, it had long been widely popular. In cities such as [[Damascus]], [[Cairo]] and [[Istanbul]], embroidery was visible on handkerchiefs, uniforms, flags, [[Islamic calligraphy|calligraphy]], shoes, robes, tunics, [[Horse tack|horse trappings]], slippers, sheaths, pouches, covers, and even on leather belts. Craftsmen embroidered items with [[gold]] and [[silver]] thread. Embroidery cottage industries, some employing over 800 people, grew to supply these items.<ref name=Stone>{{cite journal |url=http://archive.aramcoworld.com/issue/200703/the.skill.of.the.two.hands.htm |publisher=Aramco World |title=The Skill of the Two Hands |author=Stone, Caroline| volume=58 |issue=3 |date=May 2007}}</ref>
In the 16th century, in the reign of the [[Mughal Emperor]] [[Akbar]], his chronicler [[Abu al-Fazl ibn Mubarak]] wrote in the famous ''[[Ain-i-Akbari]]'':
[[File:18th century Ottoman barber apron.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] barber's apron. Embroidery with silver and silk thread on wool. 18th century]]
{{quote|His majesty [Akbar] pays much attention to various stuffs; hence [[Iran]]i, [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]], and [[Mongolia]]n articles of wear are in much abundance especially textiles embroidered in the patterns of ''Nakshi'', ''Saadi'', ''Chikhan'', ''Ari'', ''Zardozi'', ''Wastli'', ''Gota'' and ''Kohra''. The imperial workshops in the towns of [[Lahore]], [[Agra]], [[Fatehpur Sikri|Fatehpur]] and [[Ahmedabad]] turn out many masterpieces of workmanship in fabrics, and the figures and patterns, knots and variety of fashions which now prevail astonish even the most experienced travellers. Taste for fine material has since become general, and the drapery of embroidered fabrics used at feasts surpasses every description.<ref name=Werner>{{cite journal |last1=Werner |first1=Louis |title=Mughal Maal |url=http://archive.aramcoworld.com/issue/201104/mughal.maal.htm |publisher=Aramco World| volume=62 |issue=4 |date=July 2011}}</ref>}}
Embroidery offered symbolic protection for the most highly valued objects, including babies, household possessions and things with religious significance. When in the 16th and 17th centuries in Turkey, men wore [[turban]]s as a sign of Islam, they placed their turbans under embroidered cloths.<ref>Paine, p. 160</ref>
==Techniques==
[[File:Turkish - Mirror Cover - Walters 83214 - Detail.jpg|thumb|left|[[Turkey|Turkish]] Mirror Cover with floral ornament based on Ottoman ceramics. A [[superstition]] warned against looking into a mirror at night. 18th century]]
A wide variety of embroidery techniques were used across the Islamic world, with an equally broad range of materials.<ref>Gillow and Sentance, pp. 174–203</ref>
[[Uyghurs|Uighur]] women embroider [[felt]] [[Taqiyah (cap)|skull caps]], for use on their own or as the base for a [[turban]].<ref>Gillow and Sentance, p. 171</ref>
In Morocco and Tunisia, [[satin stitch]] was used for items such as decorative curtains and mirror covers.<ref>Gillow and Sentance, pp. 174–175</ref> A form of satin stitch present in the [[Bedouin]] societies of the [[Arabian Peninsula]], sometimes referred to as ''khiyat al madrassa'' ("school embroidery"), was used for furnishings. Prior to the stitching process, a shape was drawn onto the fabric by a skilled artist. Designs incorporating natural themes such as birds or flowers were most common.<ref>{{cite book|last=Abu Saud|first=Abeer|title=Qatari Women: Past and Present|date=1984|isbn=978-0582783720|publisher=Longman Group|page=140}}</ref>
Surface satin stitch, worked only on the upper surface, is a more economical but looser technique, vulnerable to wear, and so is mainly used for special occasions. In [[Punjab]], [[Phulkari]] (flower work) shawls were however daily wear for women in the countryside, while special ones, bagh, were completely covered with embroidery and were made by maternal grandmothers for their granddaughters' weddings.<ref>Gillow and Sentance, p. 177</ref>
[[Chain stitch]], which is adaptable and relatively easy to create, was used in Persia for [[Resht]] embroidery, with densely worked flowers and [[arabesque (Islamic art)|arabesques]] on felted woollen cloths.<ref>Gillow and Sentance, pp. 178–179</ref> A type of embroidery similar to heavy chain stitch, known as ''[[Kurar (embroidery)|kurar]]'', was previously used by Bedouin to create dresses for both men and women. It required four people, with each person carrying four threads which were either of varying colors or silver and gold.<ref>{{cite book|last=Abu Saud|first=Abeer|title=Qatari Women: Past and Present|date=1984|isbn=978-0582783720|publisher=Longman Group|page=136}}</ref>
[[File:Algerian - Turban Cover - Walters 83178.jpg|thumb|[[Algeria]]n [[turban]] cover. Silk embroidery on [[linen]]. 18th century]]
[[Cross stitch]] was used across the [[Middle East]] in [[Syria]], [[Jordan]], Palestine and [[Sinai]] to work wedding dresses with bold embroidery in red, with triangular [[amulet]]s or [[carnation]] flowers on a black background.<ref>Gillow and Sentance, pp.180–181</ref>
Another widely used technique, [[Herringbone stitch]], was used in [[Afghanistan]] to embroider [[bridegroom]]'s [[smock-frock|smock]]s with raised bands of red, green or white stitchery on a white background.<ref>Gillow and Sentance, pp. 182–183</ref>
[[Couching]], the stitching of decorative cord on to the surface of a fabric, was used widely across the Islamic world. In Afghanistan, a [[velvet]] dress could be worked in military style with gold-coloured threads on the front, sleeves and hem. Chieftains in [[Montenegro]] could wear robes heavily couched in gold thread. In Palestine, dresses could be heavily worked in vertical panels with couched threads of metal and cotton. In Syria, jackets were couched with stylised flowers and trees. In the Northwest Frontier of [[Pakistan]], waistcoats were sewn with a combination of [[appliqué]] panels and couched metal [[braid]].<ref>Gillow and Sentance, pp. 184–185</ref>
[[File:Embroidery from Bukhara Doris Duke Foundation for Islamic Art 85.81.JPG|thumb|upright|left|Embroidered [[Suzani (textile)|Suzani]] from [[Bukhara]], [[Uzbekistan]]. Cotton with silk threads. Late 19th century]]
In [[Central Asia]], Bokhara couching using continuous thread creates spectacular [[suzani (textile)|suzani]]s, hangings for wedding halls and bridal beds. Carnation and [[pomegranate]] motifs symbolised [[fertility]]. The technique was also used in Afghanistan and [[Uzbekistan]] for horse blankets and brazier covers.<ref>Gillow and Sentance, pp. 186–187</ref>
[[Blanket stitch]], [[buttonhole stitch]], and eyelet stitch all had the original function of strengthening the edges of textiles subject to daily wear and tear, but were adapted for decorative purposes. In North Africa and the Middle East, eyelet stitch is made using a spoked wheel pattern of stitches, or in the Algerian form without an enclosing circle. In [[Turkmenistan]], hook and tulip motifs could be worked in buttonhole stitch. In Afghanistan, men's shirts could be embroidered with herringbone and buttonhole stitches in white silk on white cotton, in elaborate arabesques.<ref>Gillow and Sentance, pp. 188–189</ref>
[[File:Afghanistan Smock detail.jpg|thumb|Detail of man's white [[satin stitch]] embroidered [[smock-frock|smock]] from Afghanistan. Mid 20th century.]] [[Whitework]], the use of white thread on a white ground, covers a variety of techniques and materials, and is used in different forms around the world. In [[Algeria]], [[Kabyle people|Kabyle]] women could wear whitework dresses. In [[Ghazni]], Afghanistan, men's smocks could be embroidered with geometric whitework stitching embellished with small circular mirrors.<ref>Gillow and Sentance, pp. 196–197</ref>
[[Needlepoint]] (canvaswork) was used for brightly coloured geometrical [[Hazaras|Hazara]] dress panels in Afghanistan.<ref>Gillow and Sentance, pp. 198–199</ref>
[[Smocking]] was used for men's smocks in [[Nuristan]] in the [[Hindu Kush]], the black stitching pulling the cloth into vertical bands with zigzag, crisscross and other simple geometric patterns.<ref>Gillow and Sentance, pp. 200–201</ref>
Tambour work, a rapid form of embroidery using a fine ari hook instead of a needle, was one of the techniques used around [[Bokhara]] in Uzbekistan for suzanis.<ref>Gillow and Sentance, pp. 202–203</ref>
==Symbolism==
Embroidered motifs often carry symbolic meaning. A widespread symbol across the Islamic world (and also often found on [[Islamic carpet]]s) is the [[tree of life]], signifying birth, growth to maturity, death and rebirth. It can be shown in many forms, such as a deliberately stylised tree, sometimes flanked by pairs of birds or fruits such as pomegranates, or a vase of flowers.<ref>Paine, pp. 70–72, 88–89, etc.</ref>
==Decline==
[[File:Six cushions from Palestine.jpg|thumb|upright=1.5<!--size for multiple image-->|Modern [[Palestinian territories|Palestinian]] [[cross-stitch]] cushions. From top left, clockwise: [[Gaza City|Gaza]], [[Ramallah]], Ramallah, [[Nablus]], [[Beit Jalla]], [[Bethlehem]].]]
Embroidery was important in traditional cultures across the Islamic world. The [[Industrial Revolution]] made colourful clothing available more quickly and more cheaply, displacing crafts such as embroidery.<ref name=Paine177>Paine, pp. 177–178</ref>
For example, the [[masnat]] (enthronement) cloths of [[Hyderabad, India]] were made of velvet, hand-embroidered with glittering [[copper]] thread forming gold- and silver-coloured flowers (formerly actually of those metals). These were made for [[Mughal Empire|Mughal]] emperors and other rulers, and also for the bride and groom to sit on during weddings in Hyderabad. The technique derived from Turkey and Persia. A masnat takes between twelve days and two months to make, and can cost up to 100,000 rupees. Business declined during the 20th century, as fewer traditional cloths were ordered. Wedding providers offered a masnat as part of their service; machine-made cloths edged out handmade ones. As of 2012, only a few elderly masnat makers remained.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Mohammed |first1=Syed |title=Technology rings death knell for masnat makers |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/hyderabad/Technology-rings-death-knell-for-masnat-makers/articleshow/11680587.cms?referral=PM |publisher=[[Times of India]] |accessdate=16 December 2015 |date=30 January 2012}}</ref>
The embroidery researcher Sheila Paine concludes her book ''Embroidered Textiles'' by explaining that<ref name=Paine177/>
{{quote|once the social context no longer exists and the beliefs and fears that embroidery promoted or deflected no longer torment, once linen is no longer painfully cultivated, spun and woven, sheep are no longer the mainstay of life and exotic silks from other lands a precious luxury – then traditional embroidery is doomed.<ref name=Paine177/>}}
Among the causes of embroidery's decline are [[politics]] and [[economics]], but Paine suggests that the most powerful factor has been the [[education]] of young women. Embroidery is no longer the only way the young woman in Turkey or Baluchistan can secure her future by winning a husband; instead, she can aspire to a university degree and a career of her own. Paine argues that attempts to reinstate traditional embroidery, as with schools set up in Istanbul and [[Salamanca]], will inevitably fail once the necessary social environment that gave handmade artefacts meaning has collapsed. In future, she states, embroidery will carry individual meaning, as in the West, and perhaps new social purposes, as with the politically significant embroidered dresses of the Palestinians.<ref name=Paine177/><ref name=Sunbula>{{cite web|title=Craft Traditions of Palestine |url=http://www.sunbula.org/crafttrad.shtml |publisher=Sunbula |accessdate=16 December 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080321111836/http://www.sunbula.org/crafttrad.shtml |archivedate=March 21, 2008 }}</ref>
